bboxes.raw_text:
officers of the Committee on
Political Education of the AFL-
CLIO.


Answering the charge that
white workers would be dis
charged to make jobs for Ne
groes, Mr.. Wilkins read to the
group Sec. 703(j) of the law as
follows: Nothing contained in
this title shall be Interpreted to
require any employer. employ
ment agency, labor organization.
or joint labor management COM
mittee subject to this title to
grant preferential treatment to
any individual or to any group
because of race, color, religion,
sex, or national origin of such
individual or group on account
of an imbalance which may exist
with respect to the total number
or percentage of perso ns of any
race, color, religion, sex, or
national origin employed by any
employer -. in any community.
state, section or other area"
NAACP Head Says Read Rights Law

& BUCKEYE-A group ofNegroes
from Allenville, one mile south
of the city, met with the Cham
Der ofCommerce. They pr otested
contaminated water, poor police
protection and inadequate bus
service for school children.


Abraham Harris, chairman of
the group, said some CORE mem
bers from Phoenix had been in
vited to the meeting. The pres
ence of the CORE representa-
tives was Objectionable to Bill
Flower, president of the Cham
Der of commerce.


Mrs. Brady McG owan, pastor
of Allensville Mount Zion Baptist
Church, testified at the meeting.

WASHINGTON = In view of the
many distortions Of the provi-
sions of the Civil Rights Act of
1864 being circulated by anti
Negro groups, "voters hould read
the text of the law for themselves
to see what it is and what 1t is
not" NAACP Executive Secre-
tary Roy Wilkins told AFL-CIO
leaders here at a conference,
Sept. 3.


The conference, called by the
labor organization to map plans
for involving its members in
active support of enforcement
of the new law, was attended by
ESQ national, state and local trade
union leaders who heard ad-
dresses also by former Florida
Gov. Leroy Collins. director of
the Community Relations Service
established by the new law;
George Meany. AFL-CIO presi-
dent; Roy Reuther and Al Barkin,

Raymond Huffstater, former
city magistrate, denied that he
had fixed his own parking tic
kets.


He was fired by acting City
Manager Charles Esser following
the recommendation of Chief
Magistrate Eugene Mangum.


The fired city magistrate was
accused of reducing fines on his
own unpaid parking tickets and
influencing another magistrate
to reduce other tickets for him.


Huffstater. an attorney, denied
charges and said he would re-
quest a hearing by an impartial
group.

City Magistrate
Fired for Fixing
His Own Tickets

in range /ovsn. See resident mgr.
6632 S. 22nd St. 4 Vineyard
Apt. 4 $3.50 including free
water, 276-H2SO.

charges and said he would re-
